The chance is never zero, but, in successful technology companies, spinoffs are rare.   They are more common in poorly performing companies, and, even then, as with the spinoff of the Avaya from Lucent (Western Electric), it is often a seemingly "legacy" division which is thought to be unlikely to do well, as a way of unburdening the parent from the inevitable destruction of value.   This corporate thinking is often mistaken:  Avaya did well, much better than Lucent, after the spinoff, once it was freed from the dead hand of the parent's management.   AWS, on the other hand, is doing very well, arguably better than Amazon as a whole, and the Amazon CEO was most recently head of AWS for a very long time and is very familiar with its strengths and weaknesses.    Amazon is committed to the long term growth of stockholder value, and having a strong cash producer, such as AWS, helps grow the overall business, much as the insurance businesses have help grow Bershire Hathaway.   Spinning off AWS would satisfy only a few AWS customers who are Amazon competitors and hesitant about trusting AWS (although necessarily with good reason), and perhaps some left-wing regulators who are against business success on principle.

In summary, inertia with natural road blocks (i.e. new CEO, year-end timing vs. core business, time it takes to build an antitrust lawsuit, AZMN has been instrumental in keeping the US economy running during covid-19) is a powerful force.  As a result, and assuming there is not a significant change in inertia in such a short period, I put the probability at 5% as a starting value. From my perspective, there are three reasons for Amazon to spin-off AWS: 1.  Regulatory Requirement Driven by Antitrust Lawsuit:  The news of antitrust lawsuits against Amazon has been increasing.  There are lawsuits from Europe (https://www.cnbc.com/2020/11/11/eu-investigates-amazon-what-it-means-for-us-antitrust-probes.html) as well as the Washington DC (https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/latest-news-headlines/dc-s-antitrust-suit-against-amazon-will-rely-on-high-burden-of-proof-8211-experts-64539029).  Further, the new FTC chair is Lina Khan, who has expressed antitrust concerns related to Big Tech (https://www.yalelawjournal.org/note/amazons-antitrust-paradox & https://www.axios.com/lina-khan-ftc-chair-tech-24fa3aa0-d3ba-47b0-bbda-db87f401ac25.html).   This takes time and it is hard.  Further,  according to form FTC chair William Kovacic in referencing the Washington DC antitrust lawsuit, "There isn't a body of litigation that has looked at this in detail, in this setting, in trial proceedings." "Without the benefit of cases that have said 'this practice is anti-competitive,' you have to explore some new terrain. The burden is always on the plaintiff to show anti-competitive effects." At the same time, the Axios article indicates, "If Khan pursues a wide-ranging regulatory agenda, as she is expected to, and quickly gets another Democratic commissioner confirmed, the FTC can move to pursue aggressive cases and enforcement, especially with the support of Congress."  Could something happen quickly?  Maybe, but it is dependent on getting another Democratic commission confirmed quickly.  If this happens, this would change my probability. 2.  Shareholder or Board Activism to Unlock Latent Value:  This seems unlikely for several reasons.  (A) With a new CEO in February 2021 (https://www.vox.com/recode/22264330/amazon-ceo-andy-jassy-jeff-bezos-aws), it does not seem likely the Board of Directors would want to announce such a large corporate change in the first year with a new CEO.  (2) Amazon's retail business is in high gear around Christmas.  This is an enormously important time of the year.  Taking focus away from execution would be problematic in my opinion and damage the new CEO's credibility.  (3) With the annual shareholder meeting most likely in May 2022 (based on 2019 - 2021 timing), it would make the most sense to announce a spin-off in Q1'2022 or at the annual shareholder meeting itself.   (4) With a significant portion of the profitability of AMZN associated with AWS, which is important to create investments in other business units, it is not clear where the new incremental free cash flow would be sourced to fund innovation in the rest of the business.  As a result, it is not obvious a spin-off is accretive to shareholders, who are typically focused on long-term growth opportunities.  If AMZN turns into a value-oriented firm whereby generating free cash flow to return to shareholders via dividends and share buybacks, I could see a reason for AWS to spin-off.  That does not seem to be the case today. 3. Game Theory:  With increasing pressure from antitrust regulators around the world, the most cooperative Big Tech firm to regulatory changes may be able to better control the impact of regulation on their core business.  This may be in the form of a settlement with a multi-year implementation or the creation of internal firewalls between subsidiaries (i.e. large commercial banks such as Bank of America or JP Morgan).  As this type of game theory takes multiple months to negotiate, raise through proper channels, and would likely need board approval, unless it is already being discussed, it is less likely to happen before 1 January 2022.
